headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day and welcome to the Macy’s, Inc. Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to your host, Karen Hoguet. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day and welcome to the Macy’s, Inc. Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to your host, Karen Hoguet. Please go ahead.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you. Good morning. I'm Karen Hoguet, CFO of the company.Any transcription or other reproduction of the statements made in this call without our consent is prohibited. A replay of the call will be available on our website, www.macysinc.com,
componenttext:
Great. Thank you. Good morning. I'm Karen Hoguet, CFO of the company.
Any transcription or other reproduction of the statements made in this call without our consent is prohibited. A replay of the call will be available on our website, www.macysinc.com, beginning approximately two hours after the call concludes. Please refer to the Investor Relations section of our website for discussion and reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures discussed this morning.
Keep in mind that all forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions mentioned today due to a variety of factors that affect the company, including the risks specified in the company's most recently filed Form 10-K and 10-Q.
We were very pleased with our results during the third quarter. While sales were a little bit softer than we had hoped in early October with the unexpectedly warm weather, especially relative to last year, we exceeded our sales and profit plan for the quarter. And given our confidence in our business trend, we utilized $500 million of excess cash to buy back debt with maturities between 2011 and 2016 during the quarter in the open market. That brings our total debt reduction this year to over $1.2 billion, including the $150 million we paid at maturity on November 1. 
In the third quarter, our sales were $5,623,000,000, and on a comp-store basis, sales grew 3.9%. It was a good quarter overall for sales. We opened two Macy's stores in California that had been Gottschalks stores, bringing our total Gottschalks conversions up to four. These converted stores are performing very well. 
As we look by family of business, the standout performances on the positive side in the quarter came from fashion watches, our I.N.C. brand, cosmetics and fragrances, Men's and luggage. Other private brands and exclusives also had a very good quarter. The weakest performances were in cold-weather goods, traditional women's sportswear and tabletop. Geographically, we performed best across the south, all the way from Florida to Southern California where weather was less of an issue. Business, as you might imagine, was weaker in the northern climate zones due in large part to the warm weather.
The exception to this was the upper Midwest, the Chicago, Minneapolis and Detroit areas, which had a very strong performance for the third year in a row. macys.com also continued to grow rapidly in the third quarter. The growth in online sales can be attributed to a combination of better merchandising, new technologies like faceted navigation and quick view and a constant focus on omni-channel tactics.
Our digital marketing included the more aggressive use of social media and it's very closely linked with the stores providing a seamless experience for our customers. Also, our recent rollout of what we call Search and Send, where we can satisfy customer demand for items that are either not carried in a particular store or that are out of stock. We can satisfy them using the dot-com inventory. This has been very successful although these sales are not counted in our online sales. As of the third quarter, the Search and Send technology was available to customers in all of our Macy’s stores. 
Bloomingdale's performed well in the quarter, with strong sales both in the stores and also online. In fact, Bloomingdale's sales trend has been comparing favorably to other upscale fashion retailers. The Santa Monica store opened in the quarter and opened very strong, as did our first three outlet stores. The fourth outlet store is expected to open next week.
Gross margin in the third quarter was 40%, which is up 20 basis points from last year had the current accounting treatment been in effect, but down 20 basis points from last year on a reported basis. This is as anticipated and consistent with our prior guidance of a flattish gross margin rate for the fall season, meaning the third and fourth quarters combined.
We ended the third quarter with inventory up 1.9%. And while higher than it has been, the inventory level is still well below our comp store sales trend. We have focused on building fresh inventories in opportunity areas to help drive our fourth quarter sales.
SG&A in the quarter was $2,069,000,000, only up 0.6% had the accounting treatment been effect last year, and up 1.8% as reported. And as a percent of sales, SG&A was 36.9%, down 120 basis points from last year compared to the adjusted number, or down 160 basis point on a reported basis. This was also consistent with our guidance for the fall season.
Operating income in the third quarter was $177 million, more than double last year's $88 million before division consolidation costs. And as a percent of sales, operating income in the quarter was 3.1% versus 1.7% last year before division consolidation costs.
Interest expense in the quarter was $164 million, including $39 million of the non-recurring premium and fees associated with our open market debt repurchase. Excluding this, interest expense would have been $125 million, down from last year's $137 million and slightly lower than expectations.
Net income in the quarter was $10 million, or $0.02 per share. Excluding the non-recurring expenses associated with the debt buyback, EPS was $0.08 per share compared to last year's loss of $0.03, excluding division consolidation costs.
Cash flow from operating activities was $346 million for the 39 weeks of 2010, down $60 million from last year. But remember that we contributed $325 million to the pension plan as of this point in the year versus approximately $146 million last year, which reduced our cash flow from operating activities year-over-year by $179 million.
Cash flow from investing activities was roughly the same as last year, and we used $1,032,000,000 for financing activities this year versus $926 million last year. And at the end of the third quarter, we had $715 million of cash and cash equivalents on the balance sheet versus $581 million last year. This demonstrates the cash flow potential of this business given how much debt we have eliminated this year while at the same time, supporting the capital needs of the company.
It was a good quarter, and we are now ready for the fourth quarter. So let's move on and talk about our guidance.
As we look at sales for the fourth quarter, our guidance is for a comp store increase of 3% to 4%. And we're anticipating approximately 130-basis point spread between total sales growth and comp store sales growth for the fourth quarter. We are expecting a lower gross margin rate in the fourth quarter than both the reported and adjusted rates last year. You'll recall that last year's gross margin rate in the fourth quarter was unusually high, even beating that of 2007. As we guided at the end of the second quarter, the gross margin rate for the fall season would be flattish compared to last year's adjusted number, and we would give that same guidance today.
We are expecting a larger increase in SG&A dollars in the fourth quarter than that, that we experienced in the third quarter due to a shift in marketing dollars from earlier in the year and also last year's Visa and MasterCard settlement. SG&A dollars for the two quarters combined is consistent though with prior guidance. And we continue to expect the SG&A as a percent of sales to decline compared to last year's adjusted number for both the fourth quarter and for the fall season.
Interest expense is now expected to be approximately $118 million in the fourth quarter, reflecting the reduction in debt. This is about $20 million below last year. EPS is expected to be $1.42 to $1.47 in the fourth quarter, or $1.50 to $1.55 for the fall season, excluding the debt premium. And this is consistent with the increased guidance that we provided last week.
So for the full year, assuming we achieve the fourth quarter as guided, EPS, excluding the non-recurring premiums associated with both the first and third quarter debt buybacks, would be $1.94 to $1.99. This compares to $1.41 last year, excluding asset impairment charges and division consolidation costs, or an increase of 38% to 41%. This would represent terrific performance.
We have momentum as we enter the fourth quarter. The My Macy's localization and field empowerment is making an enormous difference, and we have new initiatives this fall that are also helping to accelerate our comp store sales growth. The two biggest initiatives I'd like to highlight this morning are our M.A.G.I.C. selling program and our gift strategy.
For M.A.G.I.C. selling, as you know, this summer, we trained approximately 130,000 sales associates and sales managers on selling skills, and we are giving seasonal hires a shortened form of this training. Many of you have asked us what M.A.G.I.C.  steps stands for. The M is for meet and make a connection; the A, ask questions and listen; G, give options and give advice; I, inspire to buy; and C, celebrate the purchase. We also are working with our selling managers to improve their coaching skills as an ongoing follow-up to this training.
And our gift strategy, we actually started developing our gift strategy for this holiday season in May of 2009 as soon as the new organization was put together, with the focus being on developing unique and fabulous product. As I look at this year's gift strategy, there's really three new components I'd like to highlight. The first is we have new gift shops in 400 doors, which feature limited-edition, exclusive fun gifts that are mostly under $50. And these shops, the G-Shops, will be year round, not just for Christmas.
The second would be our creative be-theme shops like be warm, be pampered, be glamorous, et cetera, that are across all families of business. And the third is our celebrity designer gifts. These are terrific exclusive selections from our celebrity designers like Jessica Simpson, Tommy Hilfiger, Ralph Lauren, Martha Stewart, Calvin Klein, Michael Kors, Rachel Roy, Kenneth Cole. I could keep going, and as you walk through our stores today, you'll see these throughout the store.
And all of these great new product offerings are being presented in new and very interesting ways, both in our stores and also online. And the products are supported by a terrific marketing campaign.
Our organization is ready and prepared to execute the fourth quarter to a whole new level. We believe we have generated significant momentum in the business, and we expect customers to react well to the newness in our assortments, our engaged selling efforts and our marketing. We hope you will all get out and check out our stores and hopefully, do some holiday shopping.
And with that, I'll take your questions.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go first to Deborah Weinswig with Citi.

componenttextpreview: So the Upper Midwest, you mentioned continues to be strong, and if memory serves me correct, that was one of the first regions that took on My Macy's. Can you elaborate on what you think continues to make that region so successful?
componenttext: So the Upper Midwest, you mentioned continues to be strong, and if memory serves me correct, that was one of the first regions that took on My Macy's. Can you elaborate on what you think continues to make that region so successful?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think when you implement My Macy's in the localization, it is not a one-shot deal. Many of you think you come in, you understand the customer and you're done. And we're finding year after year, where we're finding it, we're taking bigger bets
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think when you implement My Macy's in the localization, it is not a one-shot deal. Many of you think you come in, you understand the customer and you're done. And we're finding year after year, where we're finding it, we're taking bigger bets as we get more confident in our localization, and we think that this benefits are going to be sustainable for many, many years, and we'll just continue to build as we go forward.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: We are testing that as we move into the fourth quarter and really no update in terms of the benefits that we expect. I mean the hope, frankly, is that we provide better service, more importantly, than the expense savings.

componenttext: Well, the third quarter sales were strong. So I have to believe that the M.A.G.I.C. selling was a piece of those results, and anecdotally, and even many of you have called recognizing a difference as they've been in our stores. But again, it's hard to know what's what. But clearly, I think that is part of the strong results we've been seeing.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: And we'll go next to Charles Grom with JPMorgan.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you guys continue to delever, I was wondering if you could give us an estimate of what you think the optimal capital structure for you guys is going to be going forward? And then separately, do you expect to make any more cash pension contributions in
componenttext: As you guys continue to delever, I was wondering if you could give us an estimate of what you think the optimal capital structure for you guys is going to be going forward? And then separately, do you expect to make any more cash pension contributions in 2011?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard to give you that answer. I think we're going to wait until we get through Christmas, and then think through debt reduction strategies from there, in terms of your first question. And on the pension contributions, you had asked about 2011 and cle
componenttext: It's hard to give you that answer. I think we're going to wait until we get through Christmas, and then think through debt reduction strategies from there, in terms of your first question. And on the pension contributions, you had asked about 2011 and clearly, we will be making an additional pension contribution in 2011. And again, we also could potentially make one at the end of this year. So as we think about debt, the pension underfunding is another form of debt, that we are also addressing as part of the debt reduction strategy.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I know you guys are doing a lot more collaboration with your vendors, and I'm curious what they're saying with regards to higher sourcing costs, particularly in the second half of next year?
componenttext: And then I know you guys are doing a lot more collaboration with your vendors, and I'm curious what they're saying with regards to higher sourcing costs, particularly in the second half of next year?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is obviously a question that many of you have been calling about and clearly, there are pressures with the sourcing costs, particularly, as you said, for the back half of 2011. And one of the things you need to keep in mind is that, we, both at
componenttext: Yes, this is obviously a question that many of you have been calling about and clearly, there are pressures with the sourcing costs, particularly, as you said, for the back half of 2011. And one of the things you need to keep in mind is that, we, both at Macy’s and Bloomingdale's, have the benefit of being more of a fashion retailer and having a higher fashion content in our merchandise, which means that the input cost represents a lower percent of cost of sales and also, it gives us more flexibility in terms of the production, locale and also the materials we're using. So frankly, we are in a relatively better position than many of our competitors. But as you said, this is where our increased collaboration with our vendors is going to pay off, both in addressing the sourcing challenges and working together to minimize those. And also, the collaborations are giving us opportunity to reduce other costs of doing business together, which will help us to offset some or all of the increases in the cost of goods. I should also add that, as you think about our private brands, while we're on this subject, we have a terrific sourcing organization with very strong relationships with our manufacturing partners. This, too, will help us minimize any impact we're seeing.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you remind us what the mix is of private and exclusives, Karen, at the end of the third quarter?
componenttext: Can you remind us what the mix is of private and exclusives, Karen, at the end of the third quarter?

componenttext: Well, private is about 20%, and when we include exclusives and limited distribution, it's north of 40%.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: And then my last question, if I look at 2010 SG&A growth, it looks like it's maybe 1% to 1 ½%, roughly speaking. When we think about '11, is that a pretty good ballpark for us to think about? Or is there any catch-up costs that could come into the pipeline next year?

componenttext: Well, remember this year, we were still recognizing savings from the My Macy's consolidation. So while it seems like ancient history, we were still getting some of the benefits this year. So expense, I would expect to grow probably faster than that. But still, a lot of leverage in the business.

componenttext: Just one more question on the sourcing impact from China. I guess I was just curious to hear what you're planning on pricing, either what you're hearing from vendors about pricing programs? And then also, on the private label side, do you intend to start to raise prices to try to offset some of these costs?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's early to be able to really give you that answer. We are going to be very thoughtful about our pricing decisions. We're going to review our strategies at retail and really think through. I mean the key is we want to maintain a very high level
componenttext: I think it's early to be able to really give you that answer. We are going to be very thoughtful about our pricing decisions. We're going to review our strategies at retail and really think through. I mean the key is we want to maintain a very high level of value for our customers but at the same time, obviously, we also want to maximize sales and margin. So I think it's too early to say.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then any early learnings from the Santa Monica store that could potentially get you to increase the number of Bloomingdale's store openings in the coming years?
componenttext: And then any early learnings from the Santa Monica store that could potentially get you to increase the number of Bloomingdale's store openings in the coming years?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, on one hand, I should say it's way too early to judge. On the other hand, it's hard to not be very excited about Santa Monica. And it's really a smaller Bloomingdale's format. So again, too early to say. But my suspicion is we can open other smaller
componenttext: Well, on one hand, I should say it's way too early to judge. On the other hand, it's hard to not be very excited about Santa Monica. And it's really a smaller Bloomingdale's format. So again, too early to say. But my suspicion is we can open other smaller Bloomingdale's in similar areas.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michelle Clark with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michelle Clark with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question for you, gross margin outlook to be down in the fourth quarter both on an adjusted as well as a reported basis. If you could just walk through some of the assumptions behind that, what are you expecting for the promotional environment i
componenttext: The first question for you, gross margin outlook to be down in the fourth quarter both on an adjusted as well as a reported basis. If you could just walk through some of the assumptions behind that, what are you expecting for the promotional environment in the fourth quarter? Are you canning for the fact that December of last year was one of the coldest on record and this December forecasted to be a bit warmer? Maybe walk through some of the expectations there. And then the second question, any updates from discussions with the rating agencies? Any sense of when we could see a return in Macy’s to investment grade here?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of your first question on the gross margin rate, as I said, this is consistent with what we've been planning all fall season, so there's really no news. As you'll recall last year in the fourth quarter, it was record high, and we just think it's
componenttext: In terms of your first question on the gross margin rate, as I said, this is consistent with what we've been planning all fall season, so there's really no news. As you'll recall last year in the fourth quarter, it was record high, and we just think it's going to be hard to beat that this year. So again, we aren't expecting it to be any more promotional than last year. It's just that when we look at the timing of markdowns and how the quarter should end up, our merchants believe it's unrealistic to expect to increase that margin yet again. But again, that's not new news, and we aren't expecting it to be any more promotional. In terms of the rating agencies, we've not had any meaningful conversations through the year. And frankly, until we get through the fourth quarter, I'll be superstitious and let's just wait and talk to them then. But clearly, reducing debt and reducing the pension underfunding this year, clearly, makes our balance sheet significantly stronger in combination with the significant increase in EBITDA this year. And I think as you've read the reports this year, they are taking note. What that means in terms of investment grade timing, I can’t speak for them.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: And we'll go next to Bob Drbul with Barclays Capital.

componenttextpreview: The first one is, can you maybe talk a little bit about small market stores and how they’ve been trending versus the rest of the stores? And the second question is, in the Bloomingdale's outlet strategy, just maybe you could elaborate with some of the e
componenttext: The first one is, can you maybe talk a little bit about small market stores and how they’ve been trending versus the rest of the stores? And the second question is, in the Bloomingdale's outlet strategy, just maybe you could elaborate with some of the early learnings on what we've seen so far?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the second question, which is far too early to really be speculating. They're doing well versus what we had expected. But again, it is early. But we're very optimistic, and we think we have a good strategy there, a great team and we're w
componenttext: Let me start with the second question, which is far too early to really be speculating. They're doing well versus what we had expected. But again, it is early. But we're very optimistic, and we think we have a good strategy there, a great team and we're watching these four very closely. In terms of the small market stores, I can't answer small market but I can answer small stores. Some of those would be in larger markets but fill-in stores. And interestingly, the spread between our largest and smallest is more narrow than it's ever been. And in fact, some of our smaller stores in the third quarter were the strongest. So one of the thoughts, as you know, behind My Macy's was to help the smaller doors do better, and that does appear to be working.

componenttext: Well, so if you look at the third quarter and the fourth quarter together, it will be close to that. Remember, I said the fourth quarter, about 130 basis points? componenttext: Karen, a couple of questions on expenses and gross margin rate. When you look at the third quarter, was there a big delta in the credit incentive income that comes off the portfolio that would have an impact on the SG&A rate? headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: No, in fact, the opposite as we look to the fourth quarter. And the reason for that is, you're right, the losses are coming down, and that's obviously a benefit. But with the CARD Act and the changes associated with that, there's actually pressure in the fourth quarter on the credit line versus a year ago, it's actually expected to be worse.

componenttext: And maybe specifically, as you talk about you're looking to invest in some of the fresh, build some fresh areas, where the inventory is, where you're focused for the holiday season?

componenttextpreview: Well, I mean it's the parts of the business that have been doing well, and that we think will do well. Obviously, the gift categories, Men's, many of the home areas, luggage, fashion watches, cosmetics, I mean you can go through them, and places like I.N.
componenttext: Well, I mean it's the parts of the business that have been doing well, and that we think will do well. Obviously, the gift categories, Men's, many of the home areas, luggage, fashion watches, cosmetics, I mean you can go through them, and places like I.N.C. and the more newer fashion-right parts of the Women's apparel business.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then a follow-up to an earlier question and as it relates to SG&A, it sounds as if we should be expecting SG&A growth north of the 1 ½%, 2% we saw this year, but then you were quick to say but still expect leverage. So should we be thinking about com
componenttext: And then a follow-up to an earlier question and as it relates to SG&A, it sounds as if we should be expecting SG&A growth north of the 1 ½%, 2% we saw this year, but then you were quick to say but still expect leverage. So should we be thinking about comps in the 3-plus percent range for next year?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's too early to be talking about comps. Let's get through Christmas, and then we'll talk about next year.
componenttext: It's too early to be talking about comps. Let's get through Christmas, and then we'll talk about next year.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Robert Wilson with Tiburon Research Group.
componenttext: We'll go next to Robert Wilson with Tiburon Research Group.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Karen, could you comment on your credit penetration trends of late? And also, I think last quarter, you mentioned some new distribution facilities needed to be built to accommodate your e-commerce growth. Can you maybe comment on how much capital that you
componenttext: Karen, could you comment on your credit penetration trends of late? And also, I think last quarter, you mentioned some new distribution facilities needed to be built to accommodate your e-commerce growth. Can you maybe comment on how much capital that you're going to invest next year on those facilities?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of the credit penetration in the third quarter, it was actually down, about 100 basis points but still above 2008. So we are seeing pressure on the penetration, which we think is, in large part, a function of new acquisitions being more chal
componenttext: Yes. In terms of the credit penetration in the third quarter, it was actually down, about 100 basis points but still above 2008. So we are seeing pressure on the penetration, which we think is, in large part, a function of new acquisitions being more challenging relating to the CARD Act. So that has been a challenge, and again, better than two years ago. You may recall that last year as the economy was so weak, credit penetration spiked, and now we're seeing it come back to what I would call, more normal levels. And on the investment and warehouses for the direct-to-customer business, we have announced an expansion of our Portland, Tennessee facility which we will be doing, and most likely, we'll be building or taking over a new distribution center in 2011, 2012. So we're still working on the details for that. So we anticipate it will require significant capital, but at this point, can't give you a more specific number.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a ballpark on that $800 million number, how much of that might be related to the distribution facilities?
componenttext: Can you give us a ballpark on that $800 million number, how much of that might be related to the distribution facilities?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can't do that, but I can tell you that the whole direct-to-customer business could be as much as 20% or maybe a little more, and that includes the technology spend also. And remember, that business is growing over 20%. So we really do want to feel that
componenttext: I can't do that, but I can tell you that the whole direct-to-customer business could be as much as 20% or maybe a little more, and that includes the technology spend also. And remember, that business is growing over 20%. So we really do want to feel that growth.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Mike Shrekgast with Longacre.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Mike Shrekgast with Longacre.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wondering what your position is with regards to the not dot-com. And you've had this, your online business developing very nicely and I'm not sure if there's any plans to grow your investment in that, or monetize it or maybe you guys just keep it on
componenttext: Just wondering what your position is with regards to the not dot-com. And you've had this, your online business developing very nicely and I'm not sure if there's any plans to grow your investment in that, or monetize it or maybe you guys just keep it on the balance sheet. Could you just comment on that?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I can't make a comment on that. Sorry.
componenttext: No, I can't make a comment on that. Sorry.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to David Glick with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to David Glick with Buckingham Research.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just some follow-up questions on some of the category trends you're seeing. There are many months where you've talked about women's footwear, fashion jewelry, soft home, are you still seeing the same trends there heading into holiday or just maybe strong
componenttext: Just some follow-up questions on some of the category trends you're seeing. There are many months where you've talked about women's footwear, fashion jewelry, soft home, are you still seeing the same trends there heading into holiday or just maybe strong but not as strong as some of the standouts?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: They're still strong just not as strong as the standouts. I mean our business has been so strong this year, with the exception of cold weather in the third quarter and the women's traditional sportswear and tabletop. Everything else is doing quite well.
componenttext: They're still strong just not as strong as the standouts. I mean our business has been so strong this year, with the exception of cold weather in the third quarter and the women's traditional sportswear and tabletop. Everything else is doing quite well.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on that subject of traditional women's, is that do you think more of a weather issue or a fashion issue, and how much of a markdown headwind is that for you guys?
componenttext: And on that subject of traditional women's, is that do you think more of a weather issue or a fashion issue, and how much of a markdown headwind is that for you guys?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we'll know more as get through the fourth quarter. I suspect a lot of it is weather-driven not fashion, but we'll see as we get through the fourth quarter.
componenttext: I think we'll know more as get through the fourth quarter. I suspect a lot of it is weather-driven not fashion, but we'll see as we get through the fourth quarter.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of capital expenditures for next year, any thoughts on that? And then on the SG&A, your SG&A leverage comment, do you anticipate leveraging SG&A, excluding D&A, which obviously has been trending down?
componenttext: In terms of capital expenditures for next year, any thoughts on that? And then on the SG&A, your SG&A leverage comment, do you anticipate leveraging SG&A, excluding D&A, which obviously has been trending down?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Clearly, that's the challenge. So yes, I hope to, but still to be seen how much and if it's possible.
componenttext: Clearly, that's the challenge. So yes, I hope to, but still to be seen how much and if it's possible.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the CapEx?
componenttext: And then on the CapEx?

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: $800 million is what we've budgeted for next year.
componenttext: $800 million is what we've budgeted for next year.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And there are no other questions at this time. I'd like to turn the conference back over to Ms. Hoguet for any closing remarks.
componenttext: And there are no other questions at this time. I'd like to turn the conference back over to Ms. Hoguet for any closing remarks.

headline: Macy's, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: Great. Well, thank you all for your interest. And if you have further questions, feel free to call Susan or me, and take care.
